tweet: If we‚Äôre going to restore trust in government, we need to make it more accessible to those we‚Äôre serving. This is an outdated parliamentary procedure used to distort our process, not improve it. 4/4

Most recently we've seen them deployed in insincere ways to attempt to derail important legislation like universal background checks -- even though 90% of the public supports it. The American people deserve transparency and openness, not games. 3/4

MTR's have been used to sideline legislation and confuse Members and the public for years. It is a parliamentary gimmick that flies in the face of a Member of Congress's duty to carefully consider legislation before it is voted on. 2/4

A wonderful thing about being a Member of this historically large Freshman class is that we bring fresh eyes to the legislative process. One significant way we can make our government more simple, transparent, and fair is to do away with the Motion to Recommit (MTR). 1/4
I‚Äôm proud to have voted for #HR8, and will continue fighting for further gun safety reform. #ForThePeople

This tragedy devastated our whole community. As a mother, this loss still fills me with grief and anger. Today, Jody keeps her daughter‚Äôs memory alive, educates women about domestic violence, and fights for tougher gun laws.

Today I spoke on the floor about Jody Marchand from my district. Jody endured years of domestic abuse. In 2010 she survived a brutal  attack by her husband, but lost her beautiful 17-year-old daughter, Olivia, when her husband shot and killed her, and then himself.

In fact, #EqualPayForEqualWork could slash the poverty rate for all working women in half (from 8.1 percent to 3.9 percent) and the poverty rate for working single mothers would be cut by nearly half (from 28.7 percent to 15.0 percent).

The gender pay gap doesn't just affect women ‚Äì it affects children and families and our economy as a whole.

Did you know that women are the sole or co-breadwinner in half of US families with children? Providing equal pay to women would have a dramatic impact on their families.

Today, a woman still makes only 80 cents, on average, for every dollar earned by her white male counterpart. That gap is even worse for women of color.

I'm proud to have voted with @HouseDemocrats on the Education and Labor Committee to do something about it. #HR7 #EqualPay https://twitter.com/EdLaborCmte/status/1100473638355156992¬†‚Ä¶

No person should have to decide between putting food on the table or being able to care for a sick loved one.

One of the main reasons I ran for office was to make life better for women and hardworking families just like the one I grew up in. Ushering in a new, national paid family leave policy for the United States is one of the most significant steps Congress can take to do just that.

Family #PaidLeave legislation would empower women, strengthen families, support businesses, and grow the U.S. economy. I am proud to be a cosponsor, and I look forward to working with my colleagues to get this bill signed into law. https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/paid-family-leave-democrats_us_5c61bbfce4b0eec79b26b140¬†‚Ä¶

Can you imagine being forced to choose between putting food on the table or taking care of a sick loved one? No one should have to think about it, let alone experience it. That is why I am a cosponsor of the #FAMILYAct. It is time for a national #PaidLeave policy that works.

LGBTQ+ people often have to face down additional hurdles to access paid family leave. Passing the #FAMILYAct would ensure they don't risk their economic livelihood to care for a loved one. 

Thank you, @HRC, for being an ally in the fight for #PaidLeave!

The #FAMILYAct would guarantee #PaidLeave for moms and dads (and many others!). A national paid leave policy is urgently needed to shift care-giving norms and to make workplaces more equitable and family friendly. I am proud to cosponsor this legislation. pic.twitter.com/zSowVxz403
